Comments_List:
A more nuanced understanding of oil beyond what we typically see on tv/newspapers etc
An understanding of the structures and processes that have been created for/by oil and how they are reproduced to ensure that oil is an integral part of society (not just American although predominantly so)
Insights into ethnographies, visual essays, documentaries and other forms of media
Ability to analyze these different forms of media and apply the frameworks taught earlier in the class
How to think about the social and cultural ideas around not only oil, but many objects in life. A great way to learn how to interpret the world in a nuanced way

Strengths:
Exposure to different styles of anthropological writing
Seminar structure of class that ensured we were all engaged and talking rather than being lectured
Feedback provided on assignments and manner in which they were structured (annotated bibliography, two page proposal etc)
Gained common understanding even by those without anthropology background
No one was left on their own
Strengths could be to break off a section for more those wanting more advanced seminar. Overall, one of the best classes at YAle

I thought the midterm "exam" paper is a real strength of the course. I think more professors should use this model. I enjoyed how we are all given the same "archive" and asked to write a paper. I think this focuses students' attention on critical analysis. 

Weaknesses: I thought that discussions sometimes got off track. It was hard to follow people's thinking at times. This is not so much a weakness of the course, but simply an observation. I'm not sure if there's a way to have student's do some intellectual work before class-time so they can refine their thinking a bit. One model I've found useful is having student's write "thesis sentences" for each of the readings prior to class. This helps the students distill what the main thesis of each reading was. This adds to the workload, so maybe cutting a couple readings/chapters from each week would be necessary. I think this would help students focus in on some readings each week and really understand them. This deeper understanding would lead to better discussions. Just some ideas/hypotheses...
Definitely there is much more to oil than meets the eye!
Yes. It was engaging and I learned about the topic from a wide perspective.

Absolutely! I think this is a really fantastic course. If you are interested in energy and anthropology this is the course to take. Also, Doug Rogers is a really encouraging and helpful professor. In terms of readings, some weeks are better than others, but overall it's an engaging course.
